content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins:

  • WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , its time for our weekly triage meeting. Leave a :wave: to show you're here!
(today is my first day using the keybindings for emojis and edits, and I'm already so psyched.)

We'll start off with ~6 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow 2022-02-11T15:00:00+01:00, monthly Compiler Team Planning meeting

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copyright/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).

• pnkfelix sent out an email to the T-compiler{,-contributors}, with a draft of a blog post listing our Ambitions for 2022. I'm going to be proposing a steering meeting dedicated to that topic, presumably for a week from tomorrow. But you all can and should read that doc before then; the sooner we get feedback, the easier it will be to adapt it into the doc.
(You can see more dialogue about this at #t-compiler > roadmap for 2022 discussion . )
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 7 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 4 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "Build-time execution sandboxing" compiler-team#475 (last review activity: about 44 days ago)
    • "Dealing with type/const ambiguities" compiler-team#480 (last review activity: about 20 days ago)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize let else" (draft) rust#93628

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Overhaul interning" compiler-team#481
    • "Simplify rustc_codegen_llvm::debuginfo::metadata" compiler-team#482

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking issue for #[cfg(target_has_atomic = ...)]" rust#32976
    • "Stabilize -Z instrument-coverage as -C instrument-coverage" rust#90132

pnkfelix said:

  • Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize let else" (draft) rust#93628

oh, sorry, that's an FCP for T-lang, not T-compiler
WG checkins

• WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli (previous checkin)
    • rust#92306 fixed a major blocker (there are only diagnostic blockers left) for stabilizing nll

No big items from Wg-diagnostics this past cycle (other than several changes around Tait), but I hope that by the next check-in I will have put in place regular meetings and grown the number of contributors working on this space.

pnkfelix said:

  • WG-diagnostics by Esteban Küber and oli (previous checkin)
    • rust#92306 fixed a major blocker (there are only diagnostic blockers left) for stabilizing nll

I'm not sure if the statement "there are only diagnostic blockers left" is accurate; there's a chat in #t-compiler > roadmap for 2022 discussion that mentions the "leak check" is still something we need to resolve for NLL, I think.

• WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Yuki Okushi (previous checkin)

    Most notable changes

    • Clean up section about FCPs #1287
    • Streamline "Getting Started" some more. #1286

    Most notable WIPs

    • Describe Type Alias Impl Trait (TAIT) Inference Algorithm #1297
    • method-lookup.md improvements #1296
    • Extend debugging llvm section #1290
    • Added detail to codegen section #1216
    • Update build instructions for rustdoc #1117
    • Document inert vs active attributes #1110
    • Explain the new valtree system for type level constants. #1097
Can I just say that the rustc-dev-guide is a treasure?
Thank you to everyone who's been working to curate that.
Okay lets move on to...

Backport nominations

T-compiler beta / T-compiler stable

• "Fix invalid special casing of the unreachable! macro" rust#93179
    • Fixes T-libs p-high issue rust#92137 about the unreachable!() macro behaviour in edition 2021
    • also nominated for stable backport
    • @simulacrum remarks that the perf regression is not due to this PR but to the codegen unit (see comment)
omg key bindings soooo good
so lets see, release is in two weeks
@simulacrum can you remind me when we'll do the crater run against the 1.59-beta branch?
it's already done
and we won't do another one?
I ask because the comment thread for rust#93179 included someone asking if the PR would get a crater run
we typically do not
okay
but I can queue one up
after this backport
so wait, I'm not sure If I'm clear
do we do another crater run when we take the beta and promote it to stable prior to a release?
how severe is this bug?
I can't quite tell from the PR
the relevant bug is #92137
I see, it's because of fmt capture

pnkfelix said:

do we do another crater run when we take the beta and promote it to stable prior to a release?

we typically do a crater run directly after master -> beta promotion and no subsequent ones close to release,
(iow backports are not typically crater'd)
huh. okay.
That's... Scary
but it's mostly a matter of timing and having hands to analyze results etc
so that seems like there's an failure mode where something goes into beta (via backport) and then stable (via normal promotion) that has never been through a crater run?
Yes, though we'll pick it up on the next crater run (a week or so after stable release), in theory.
yeah I can see there are tradeoffs here: we can't afford to crater-run+analysis for every single backport, and we want the freeedom to do backports relatively close to release
anyway
If we can do a crater run in time, then I'm in favor of doing a backport here
I'm willing to drive analyzing the results if necessary.
if we cannot get a crater run in, then I'm not so certain about beta-backport.
and I'm pretty sure we won't approve this for stable-backport without a crater run.
the main motivation for beta-backport is to avoid it being in 2 releases on stable
(plus the release is in two weeks)
right?
I think so?

in some sense the risk only goes up over time.

anyway, I think we can get a crater run in.
That is the flip side: Accept the potential breakage without a crater run, because its more important to stop proliferation of the pattern
I can see both sides of that.
but it's probably best to backport and then run crater, and maybe back it out after that.
(so we automatically cover all the other backports, while we're at it)
okay then, backport approved.

• "backport llvm fix for issue 91671." rust#93426
    • opened by @pnkfelix, fixes rust#91671
    • discussed last week (Zulip archive link), backport decision postponed (comment)
so its been 13 days since this landed. I'm feeling pretty comfortable with it now
Wesley did raise the point last week of "I don't know why we'd approve this for beta and not for stable."
For now, I'd like to propose we beta-backport this but not worry about a stable-backport

but I think Wesley's point is a good one to think about moving forward. (More generally, I think we need to revise our approach to stable-backports, and make it more of a dialogue with the release team.)
(the underlying change https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm-project/compare/221a195b62f4373a8893f4d022e4ce981b09a857...b6b46f596a7d2523ee1acd1c00e699615849da60)
oh yes, thanks @Esteban Küber
okay then backport approved

• "Resolve lifetimes for const generic defaults" rust#93669
    • opened by @Michael Goulet (compiler-errors)
    • fixes P-critical rust#93647
I was tempted to unilaterally beta-approve this one
it did make me wonder: 1. is there a lint against using .. in patterns, and 2. should we consider using it?
in this case, I expect people may have just used _ anyway, so maybe it wouldn't accomplish that much. I don't know.
but then again, at least here you'd be forced to write default: _, right?
seems strictly better when it comes to the chances of noticing that something is wrong.
anyway, beta backport approved.

• "Complete removal of #[main] attribute from compiler" rust#93753
    • Removes the old #[main] and prevents future crates using it by mistake (more context in this comment)
    • a crater run should indicate if there are crate sin the wild still using this attribute
^ @simulacrum support for your argument that we should batch these together into a beta crater run

also, I want to note that its not just me who's ignorant of the timing of the beta-crater runs. @Vadim Petrochenkov commented there 2 days ago:

I suggest backporting it sooner so it gets into the beta crater run, and reverting later if there are any regressions in non-nightly crates. If there's no time for that, then land it on nightly and wait for the next beta crater run.
in other words, I'm glad I asked about that
one question about this, it says "#[main] attribute was unintentionally stabilized"
if so ... shouldn't we also stable backport this?
hey @simulacrum maybe the expected date for those scheduled beta crater runs should be part of the display on forge?
We can add a 'as soon as possible after initial promotion', I guess

Santiago Pastorino said:

if so ... shouldn't we also stable backport this?

hmm.
accidental stabilization was in 1.53
It feels like the mistake was making the macro a noop and not emit a warning or lint. Now it will be an error and break any accidental code that did... Nothing.

simulacrum said:

accidental stabilization was in 1.53

ohh ok, and also the release is very close :)
yeah the risks associated with a stable backport strike me as outweighing the gains
okay, beta backport approved for PR #93753

• "Fix invalid special casing of the unreachable! macro" rust#93179
    • discussed in beta-backport
I don't have an issue with backporting this, but we really need a crater run (as already discussed).
it definitely needs a crater run. Also, even @Mara was unsure about whether it should be backported to stable.
my current feeling is that I wouldn't stable-backport approve this.
so lets just decline for stable
@Wesley Wiser as part of our more general leadership planning, lets aim to discuss this story about stable-backports, yeah?
:thumbs_up: Sounds good

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Mir-Opt for copying enums with large discrepancies" rust#85158 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • Last T-compiler review
    • PR turned to s-waiting-on-team 2 days ago
@apiraino was that a typo? its marked s-waiting-on-review
(9 days ago, to be precise)
and @oli is back from leave now
yes, pasted from last week :angel:
so @Wesley Wiser , if you want/need to reassign it back to @oli , I think that's totally reasonable.
I think I just need to look over and r+ it again.
okay great

• "Switch to normalized triples for Fuchsia" rust#90510 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • PR assignee @Esteban Küber, reviewed also by @tmandry
    • though last comment seems to indicate it's a bit stale
huh
seems like it might need some assistance
It was approved but the pr failed roll-up. Can we ping the author again?
I recommend pinging both author and tmandry
(just because I suspect tmandry may be able to better assist the author, or finding a new owner if necessary)
done

• "Improve unsafe diagnostic" rust#91133 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • Seems PR author is asking a new review from @Esteban Küber (assigned reviewer)
I assume this is just on the low end of your priority queue, right @Esteban Küber ?
The pr... Was fine but wanted to take a different approach for these substitution errors
oh I see, so its not just a matter of review capacity, there's more serious revision you want made?
They add to our tech debt and make petrochenkov understandably sad.
okay. I'll trust you to follow up
Yes

• "Remove eval_always for privacy." rust#90581 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • PR author pushed after the last perf report (with mixed results)
    • Perhaps this is waiting on someone to trigger @rust-timer again?
actually I'm going to cut this section short
its more imporatnt that we look at other sections of agenda

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 1 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 69 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 46 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 0 P-high, 0 P-medium, 1 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 2 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 44 P-high, 82 P-medium, 12 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • "Const generic defaults ICE: No bound vars found" rust#93647
    • @Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) provided a fix in PR rust#93669 (beta-backport nominated)
okay this is under control

• "#92007 appears to break inference for previously compiling code" rust#93821
    • Caused by rust#92007
    • oli submitted PR rust#93783 for review (zulip topic)
weird, there's no backlink from PR #93783 to #92007 #93821
now I'm confused about what #93783 fixed
no they aren't related?
@apiraino was this just a mistake in relating that PR to this issue?
in any case, I'm going to assign #93821 to @oli
/me looking to establish the links with the PR
since it was bisectedt o PR #92007
I misspoke up above
It was noticed in the perf run for #92007 that it broke the gll benchmark. https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/92007#issuecomment-1032203011
ok #93783 fixes #93831 and #93821 (iiuc)

Wesley Wiser said:

It was noticed in the perf run for #92007 that it broke the gll benchmark. https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/92007#issuecomment-1032203011

I see, the bot doesn't include such breakage in its current summary
Yeah, that was mentioned as well :smile:
there are multiple bugs and multiple fix PRs :laughing:
I'm still super confused
that may be the cause of the confusion
because I thought Oli got their fix in before the nightly was made
I also didn't know about some of these issues, thus I didn't link them
but issue #93821 is about a problem detected via nightly

pnkfelix said:

but issue #93821 is about a problem detected via nightly

yea, I'm a) not sure how it's happening and b) not sure how my fix should have fixed that
so either I'm just wrong about when PR #93783 ... wait, what amI talking about, of course PR #93783 doesn't link to #93821, the latter was clearly created after teh former...

oli said:

pnkfelix said:

but issue #93821 is about a problem detected via nightly

yea, I'm a) not sure how it's happening and b) not sure how my fix should have fixed that

okay, lets just pretend no one ever claimed that PR #93783 fixed issue #93821. :)
and I'll assign issue #93821 to @oli and leave it at that. :)
next

• "Internal Compiler Error when compiling rocket = "0.5.0-rc.1"" rust#93831
    • Caused by rust#92007
    • should also be fixed by PR rust#93783 authored by oli
also assigned to @oli (already), so I'm sure it will get resolved.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
(fixed by #93859, says github backlink )
also of note: we're doing a crater run for this

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Jack Huey said:

also of note: we're doing a crater run for this

"this" being ...?
(sorry I'm going to keep working through agenda in parallel since we have such little time left)

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2022-02-02

This was a relatively quiet week with regressions and improvements relatively equally each other out. The big exception is with a somewhat large regression in rustdoc which was needed for a large and important architectural change. This could lead to users see somewhat slower doc build times with more memory used especially in projects with large crate dependency graphs.

Triage done by @rylev.
Revision range: c54dfee65126a0ac385d55389a316e89095a0713..1ea4851715893ee3f365a8ef09d47165e9a7864f

2 Regressions, 4 Improvements, 2 Mixed; 1 of them in rollups
29 Untriaged Pull Requests
35 comparisons made in total

Regressions

rustdoc: Pre-calculate traits that are in scope for doc links #88679

  • Average relevant regression: 5.4%
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 9.1% on full builds of regression-31157 doc
  • All the regressions are localized to rustdoc and are quite substantial but exacerbated by an architectural issue which needs to be solved.
  • The regressions are well known and extensively discussed in the PR with the next steps being tracked in an issue.

Store def_id_to_hir_id as variant in hir_owner. #93373

  • Average relevant regression: 1.2%
  • Average relevant improvement: -0.3%
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 5.5% on incr-unchanged builds of match-stress-enum check
  • This is the first commit (originally bundled with #93301) of a larger PR (#89278) which saw larger PR regressions than the two sub PRs combined.
  • A more detailed justification for this can be found here, but in general this allows for even more incremental compilation and is thus worth the small immediate compilation performance penalty.

Improvements

  • Fix the unsoundness in the early_otherwise_branch mir opt pass #91840
  • Only traverse attrs once while checking for coherence override attributes #93343
  • Rollup of 10 pull requests #93427
  • Disable drop range analysis #93284

Mixed

Store hir_id_to_def_id in OwnerInfo. #93301

  • Average relevant regression: 0.6%
  • Average relevant improvement: -0.5%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -0.6% on full builds of unused-warnings check
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 2.2% on incr-unchanged builds of match-stress-enum check
  • This is the first commit (originally bundled with #93373) of a larger PR (#89278) which saw larger PR regressions than the two sub PRs combined.

Create core::fmt::ArgumentV1 with generics instead of fn pointer #90891

  • Average relevant regression: 1.2%
  • Average relevant improvement: -1.2%
  • Largest improvement in instruction counts: -6.7% on full builds of tokio-webpush-simple opt
  • Largest regression in instruction counts: 2.1% on full builds of keccak check
  • The improvements outweigh the regressions considerably and this was considered a fine trade off.

pnkfelix said:

Jack Huey said:

also of note: we're doing a crater run for this

"this" being ...?

the lazy TAIT change. So we hopefully find new issues sooner than waiting for them to be filed
okay great

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • No I-compiler-nominated at this time

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
crater run for #92007 fallout tracked in #93833, fyi

Jack Huey said:

pnkfelix said:

Jack Huey said:

also of note: we're doing a crater run for this

"this" being ...?

the lazy TAIT change. So we hopefully find new issues sooner than waiting for them to be filed

I wasn't sure if you were referring to a specific PR, or what. But the point is that you're doing a crater run against the current nightly, right? Can you share a link?

Michael Goulet (compiler-errors) said:

crater run for #92007 fallout tracked in #93833, fyi

ah thank you
Okay well that's our hour
I want to remind everyone: Planning meeting tomorrow at 2022-02-11T10:00:00-05:00
and please do read the "2022 Ambitions" doc that you got in your email
let me or Wesley know if you're having trouble finding it (or having trouble understanding it, etc)
Thanks again to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!

pnkfelix said:

and please do read the "2022 Ambitions" doc that you got in your email

Did not get any link myself.
that's important to know
Oh wait, I think I recall reading something like it, but I can't find it in my inbox anymore :confused:
I'll send you a privmsg with info
Ah “Ambitions for 2022” is the title. Found it.
I also didn't get it - was it only for compiler-team? (I did find it on the compiler hackmd group though)
yeah, "T-compiler Draft Ambititions for 2022" is the full subject
@Jack Huey it was supposed to be sent to T-compiler and T-compiler-contributors
based on my understanding of the email list setup

Yeah, that's what is supposed to happen for compiler@
https://github.com/rust-lang/team/blob/master/teams/compiler.toml#L54-L55
there's no real reason that message needs to be kept secret. I'll just post its contents right here.

Hi y'all, T-compiler and T-compiler-contributors!

As mentioned in Zulip recently, Wesley and I have been trying to put together a document laying out the team's thoughts on initiatives for this year.

Here's the draft:

https://hackmd.io/Hrl30lX9Q0mbLIT4VkR_UA?view

As noted in the doc, our intent is to post this on the Inside Rust blog in the near future, circa February 18th. You can consider it an early preview; we want feedback from the members of T-compiler and T-compiler-contributors before we circulate it more broadly.

You can post feedback as a hackmd margin comment, or or send us an email, or write in a Zulip thread ( #t-compiler > roadmap for 2022 discussion )

Looking forward to what you all think!

Cheers,
Felix and Wesley
well glad it's not secret. as a not-formally-involved-yet person that's been trying to attend more of these meetings, I'll also try to give the astrological chart doc a read :smile:

Draft for next weeks' agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/MDQRCqHWSCG1HuHgHC847g?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser
  • WG-llvm by @nagisa and @Nikita Popov
hi all , has Rust a library for direct memory access and management?
@theseus yang #general would be a more appropriate place to ask. This stream is for compiler team meetings.
